IKDIA OFFICE, WHITEHALL, S.W.l. 2nd January, 1936 » Will you please refer to Bushire Express Letter of 19th September, No. 728-S of 1935, in which Loch suggested that some British firm might obtain a concession for gypsum in the Persian Gulf, and to the further papers forwarded by air mail on the 13th December, No. P.Z.8708/35. The Department of Overseas Trade have now sent us additional information. Loch referred to the Golden Valley Company. The Department of Overseas Trade state, however, that the industrial importance of gypsum and red oxide is very different. Red oxide is an essential constituent of most lead paints and the finest variety of it exists only in the Persian Gulf. Gypsum, on the other hand, is available in large quantities in different parts of the world. It is in fact produced in the United Kingdom to a considerable extent and any supplementary imports are obtained from comparatively near countries such as France, Latvia and Lieut.Colonel T.C.W.Fowle, C.B.E., Consulate-General, Bushire. Italy./iVi ■ ^ 2 . Italy. The question whether an import from abroad would he a paying proposition probably depends upon the amount of freight, and it is therefore improbable that imports from the Persian G-ulf into the United Kingdom would pay. The only other large market within reach of the Gulf would probably be India, but India apparently also mines gypsum herself and therefore there is likely to be little demand in that country. It would accordingly seem inadvisable, if only on commercial grounds, to encourage a British firm to interest itself in gypsum concessions in the Gulf, strick and Company have not, as yet, approached the Department of Overseas Trade, and if they should do so the latter do not propose to give them any more than perfunctory encouragement. I am sending a copy of this letter to Acheson and t0 Loch - Yours sincerely.

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

The main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 16; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right hand corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-15; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file discusses a letter from Messrs Frank C Strick and Company to the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf (Percy Gordon Loch) regarding the possibility of sourcing gypsum from the Persian Gulf.The enquiry results in discussion between the India Office (Maurice J Clauson) and Foreign Office (Lacy Baggallay) on the possibility of interesting a British company in pursuing gypsum concessions at Halal, Bu Musa [Abū Mūsā], Bahrain or the Persian Coast.
